case.name: Lindholm, in the matter of Opes Prime Stockbroking Limited (Administrators appointed) (Receivers and Managers appointed) (No 2) [2008] FCA 1578 (22 October 2008)

citphrases.citphrase: divorce and matrimonial causes, and in relation thereto, parental rights, and the custody and guardianship of infants
property of the parties to a marriage
custody, guardianship or maintenance of child of marriage
approval of maintenance agreement or revocation thereof
relation to proceedings for dissolution of nullity
whether laws relating to married persons within power
family law act 1975 (cth), ss. 4 , 9 (4), 39 , 64, 74 , 78 . constitutional law (cth)
power of commonwealth parliament to invest state courts with federal jurisdiction
regulation of practice and procedure of state courts
proceedings to be heard in closed court
judge and counsel not to robe
application for suppression orders relating to the names of two persons, one male, one female
power to suppress names of persons by court exercised only when necessary to do so in the interests of justice
prior publication of male person's name in court document available to public inspection

citances.sentence: 13 The power of the Court to suppress the publication of " particular evidence, or the name of a party or witness " cannot be questioned: Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 (Cth), s 50. That power has been exercised to suppress the names of parties to litigation (e.g., E v Australian Red Cross Society [1991] FCA 20 ; (1991) 27 FCR 310 at 313 to 314 per Wilcox J) and the names of those persons involved in litigation (e.g., Re Opes Prime Stockbroking Ltd (No 2) [2008] FCA 1578). The mere fact that a party may claim " embarrassment or unfortunate financial effects ", however, may not be a sufficient foundation for an order (e.g., Catena v Australian Securities and Investment Commission [2010] FCA 598 at [22] to [24] per Barker J).

Suppression orders, so called, are sometimes issued by courts so that any concurrent or associated criminal proceedings are not prejudiced. However, that is not this case. A case such as the present will only result in a suppression order being granted where it can be shown that the interests of justice will really be put at risk. Mere embarrassment or unfortunate financial effects on an appellant or their dependants or other persons are usually not sufficient: see John Fairfax v Local Court (1991) 26 NSWLR 131 at 142; Re Opes Prime Stockbroking Ltd (No 2) [2008] FCA 1578 at [11] . In essence, these are the complaints of the applicant. He is concerned about the effect publication of the AAT decision will have on his future prospects to resume in his industry. This is not a sufficient reason for the Court to grant the confidentiality orders sought.

FEDERAL COURT OF AUSTRALIA ACT 1976 - SECT 50 Prohibition of publication of evidence etc.
